conclusion: Books A and B are divided into parts, with book B being pulled using a force F.
The force F required to pull out book B decreases as the number of divisions increases.
The sliding friction force f between the contact surfaces of the paper to the pressure N is the coefficient of kinetic friction μ, i.e., μ = f/N.
The image shows two books, A and B, divided into various equal parts. A horizontal force F is applied to pull out book B.

premise: The force F required to pull out book B decreases as the number of divisions increases.
conclusion: F is inversely proportional to the number of divisions n, so F = k/n, where k is a constant.

premise: Using the data for 3 divisions, F = 10/3 N.
conclusion: The constant k is determined to be 10.

premise: The force F required to pull out book B is F = 5 N when divided into 2 equal parts.
conclusion: The sliding friction force f is equal to F in this scenario, so f = 5 N.

premise: Given μ = f/N, and N = 5 N.
